title-group.article-title: Investigation of the Energy Efficiency and CO2 Emission Characteristics of Pre-stressed Composite Beams

contrib-group.aff: Department of Architectural Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin 446-701, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Seon-Chee Park, Department of Architectural Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin 446-701, Korea. Tel. +82-31-201-3733, Fax. +82-31-204-5686, E-Mail pscgogo@khu.ac.kr

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on: Sustainable Development for Future Building

permissions.copyright-holder: International Society of the Built Environment

abstract.p: In this work, the energy efficiency and CO2 emission characteristics of a pre-stressed steel-framed reinforced concrete composite beam were investigated for application in high rise apartment buildings. The beam consisted of pre-cast and cast-in-place concrete with a structural T at the end section of the pre-cast concrete. As a result, CO2 emissions were significantly reduced by decreasing the quantity of steel. The composite beams were tested which demonstrated acceptable structural performance as flexural members. The measured flexible strengths of the pre-stressed composite beams were compared with the calculated flexural strengths based on the strain compatibility approach in the yield limit state and maximum load limit state. Good agreement between the experimental and analytical flexural capacities was observed. The application of the pre-stressed composite beams capable of enhancing energy efficiencies while decreasing CO2 emissions could provide a safe structure for a comfortable built environment and will be of great benefits to the welfare of a community as well. This work demonstrates that reduced CO2 emissions can be achieved by introducing pre-stressing in a concrete composite beam and by installing a structural T only at the end of the composite beam.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A composite beam is a structural solution composed of a combination of various materials. Composite beams are advantageous due to their structural stability, constructability, and lower cost [1–3]. As buildings become taller and larger, structural composite hybrid systems are increasingly used in building construction projects. In addition, researchers are actively studying new engineering solutions and structural systems using hybrid structures.

The steel pre-stressed composite beam introduced in this paper consists of a structural T, reinforced steel, pre-stressed steel and pre-cast concrete. The use of pre-stressed composite steel beams could result in shorter construction times and lower costs [4–7]. The strain compatibility approach used in this work allows for simplified calculations with good correlation to experimental results [8]. The energy consumption and CO2 emission of a pre-stressed composite steel beam were compared with reinforced concrete (RC) and steel-framed reinforced concrete (SRC) beams.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: A pre-stressed composite steel beam with pre-cast concrete was manufactured in a factory and carefully delivered to a construction site. Because the design of the pre-stressed composite steel beam is based on semi-dry construction techniques, the construction time would be considerably reduced.

In this paper, a design formula for the yield load and maximum load of a steel member is presented using the strain compatibility method to calculate the flexural capacities of a pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam and a pre-stressed composite steel beam [9].

sec.title: Strain Compatibility Method
sec.p: A design method known as the strain compatibility approach proposed by the AISC (American Institute of Steel Construction, Inc.) is presented in this work [10]. A procedure to calculate the flexural strength of a pre-stressed composite steel beam is then presented based on the strain compatibility approach. In estimating the flexural moment of the composite beam, the strains of all member components were calculated using proportional expressions. The stress of member components and a neutral axis location were assumed to establish an equation of equilibrium. A quadratic equation for the neutral axis was subsequently produced. The quadratic equation is derived from equilibrium equations to calculate a neutral axis. The stress and strain of each component can be determined from the calculated neutral axis. Agreement between the neutral axis location and the assumptions was confirmed.

The assumptions used for each member in order to analyze the pre-stressed composite steel beam are shown in Figure 1. An example of the yield limit derived from the assumptions defined in Figure 1 is illustrated in Figure 2. In the assumption presented therein, the yield limit state is expressed as Y. To be more specific, the assumption indicates that the stress levels of the steel flange, web, compressive reinforcement, and tensile reinforcement are in an elastic state, while the stress level of the pre-stressed steel is in a yield state. Fig. 1.
Description of the stress levels. Fig. 2.
Illustration of the stress levels.

sec.title: Calculation of the Flexural Moment of the Pre-stressed Composite Steel Beam
sec.p: Construction stage 1 considers the installation of pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam prior to the installation of concrete slab and concrete slab is installed with top reinforcing steels on the top of the pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam at Construction stage 2.

The centre of the composite beam consisted of reinforced concrete and pre-stressed steel. In the pre-stressing method used herein, pretension was adopted and a tendon was placed in a straight lengthwise line, as shown in Figure 3. This allowed for an analysis of the flexural performance of the cross-section. A cross-section of the pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam is shown in Figures 4 and 5 for Construction stages 1 and 2 which were used to calculate the equation of equilibrium in terms of assumption-based parameters. Fig. 3.
Lengthwise placement of the tendon. Fig. 4.
Cross-section of the pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam used to calculate the equation of equilibrium for Construction stage 1. Fig. 5.
Cross-section of the pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam used to calculate the equation of equilibrium for Construction stage 2.

As shown in Figure 6 is the stress distribution in each structural component of the composite beam corresponding to the strain assumptions at the yield limit state for Construction stage 1 and 2. Fig. 6.
Assumptions for the pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam in the yield limit state for Construction stage 1 and 2.

Since the construction load must be smaller than the yield load to which the pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam may be subject to at the yield limit state, only the flexural moment at the yield limit state was analyzed for Construction stage 1. The two possible stress distributions at the yield limit state are shown in Figure 7, where components in an elastic state are denoted in white. Assumption Y-#1 CRnyTRyPSny shows the yielding of tensile reinforcement, while Assumption Y-#2 CRnyTRnyPSy indicates the yielding of pre-stressed steel. Figure 8 describes another stress distribution for Construction stage 2. Fig. 7.
Two possible stress distributions in the yield limit state for Construction stage 1. Fig. 8.
Two possible stress distributions in the yield limit state for Construction stage 2.

The cross-section of the pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam used to calculate the flexural moment is shown in Figure 9 for Construction stage 1. The compressive strength of the concrete used in the beam was 38.8 MPa, with two 548.9 MPa reinforcing steels with diameter of 25 mm and two 438.2 MPa reinforcing steels with diameter of 13 mm used for tensile and compressive reinforcement, respectively. Figure 10 is the similar cross section for Construction stage 2. Fig. 9.
Cross-section of the pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam used to calculate the flexural moment for Construction stage 1. Fig. 10.
Cross-section of the pre-stressed composite steel beam used to calculate the flexural moment for Construction stage 2.

To calculate the strain (εc) of the top surface of the concrete at the yield limit state under a construction load, the Try and Error sequence in Table 1 was repeated until the strain of the pre-stressed steel reached 0.00837. The calculated strain (εc) was then used in each equation of equilibrium to obtain only one accurate neutral axis. For Assumption Y-#2 CRnyTRnyPSy, which satisfies the assumed neutral axis location and the stress state, the strain (εc) of the top concrete surface was calculated to be 0.0016834 when the yield strain of the pre-stressed steel reached 0.00837. Table 1.
Strain (εc) of the top concrete surface in the yield limit state.

4 0.001683 97.48 0.00836926

The neutral axis calculated from the equation of equilibrium was used to examine Assumption Y-#1 CRnyTRyPSny in order to detect inconsistencies in the assumption applied to the pre-stressed steel. The strain of each component and a comparison between the initial and calculated assumptions of Assumption Y-#1 CRnyTRyPSny for Construction stage 1 are shown in Table 2. The initial assumption and the calculated stress state are compared in Figure 11 for Construction stage 1. Table 3 is the similar table for Construction stage 2. The initial assumption and the calculated stress state are also compared in Figure 12 for Construction stage 2. Fig. 11.
Comparison between the initial assumption and the calculated stress state for Construction stage 1(Y-#1 CRnyTRyPSny). Fig. 12.
Comparison between the initial assumption and the calculated stress state for Construction stage 2 (Y-#1 CRnyTRyPSny). Table 2.

For the calculated concrete strain (εc) that satisfied the assumption, α and γ were calculated as 0.612 and 0.367 for Construction stage 1 from Equations (1)and (2), respectively [11]. (1) (2)
Where εcy is the strain of the top concrete surface at the yield limit state; α and γ were calculated as 0.505 and 0.356 for Construction stage 2.
The equilibrium equation of Assumption Y-#2 CRnyTRnyPSy for Construction stage 1 and 2 may be expressed as: (3)

Equation (4) is the quadratic equation of the neutral axis. As the properties of the member components were applied to the equation, the neutral axis was calculated to exist 98.48 mm and 123.59 mm for Construction stage 1 and 2 below the top concrete surface. (4)

Equation (5) was used to calculate the nominal moment capacity of the (pre-cast) pre-stressed composite steel beam for assumption Y-#2 CRnyTRnyPSy. The flexural moment was calculated to be 292.31 kN · m and 509.49 kN · m for Construction stage 1 and 2.

As shown in Table 4 is the force and flexural moment contributions of each member of the pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam in the yield limit state for Construction stage 1. The concrete on the compressive side and the pre-stressed steel on the tensile side were found to resist more of the load. The flexural moment acting on the cross-section was found to be 292.31 kN · m. The flexural moment on the compressive side was 89.06 kN · m, which accounted for 30.47% of the total flexural moment, while the flexural moment on the tensile side was 203.25 kN · m, which accounted for 69.53% of the total flexural moment. Table 5 shows force and flexural moment contributions of each component in yield limit state for Construction stage 2. Table 4.

sec.title: Experimental and Analytical Investigations
sec.p:
Four test specimens were manufactured in order to confirm the flexural performance of the pre-stressed composite steel beam. For the experimental testing, loading and unloading protocols were implemented for the simple beam specimens. Stud bolts were used to provide connections between the structural tees and the pre-cast concrete. The test set-up and a specimen ready for a loading application are shown in Figure 16. Fig. 16.
Test set-up for a pre-stressed composite steel beam.

sec.title: Load-strain Relationship
sec.p:
The calculated envelope and the experimental load-strain curve for specimen #1 are shown in Figure 17. The calculated yield load was found to be 292.31 kN, and the strain of the tensile reinforcement was 0.003807. For specimen #1, structural tees were displaced from the concrete before the yield load was reached. The load and strain of the tensile reinforcement were calculated to be 117.43 kN and 0.001300, respectively when the specimen failed. The experimental load was 124.21 kN. Even if the specimen was destroyed before the yield load was reached, the specimen satisfied the construction load of 47.44 kN, indicating that structural safety was ensured. Fig. 17.
Load-strain curve of the tensile reinforcement of specimen #1.

The calculated envelope and the experimental load-strain curve for specimen #2 are shown in Figure 18. Fig. 18.
Load-strain curve of the tensile reinforcement of specimen #2.

The analytical and experimental values obtained for specimens #1 and #2 at the pre-yield limit state are compared in Table 8. Table 8.
Comparison of the experimental and analytical values obtained for specimens #1 and #2.
Classification
Pre-yield limit state
Experimental value Analytical value Error
Specimen #1

Strain 0.001300 0.001300 0.00 (0.00%)
Specimen #2

Strain 0.001349 0.001349 0.00 (0.00%)
Average
Load (kN) 122.17 127.31 −5.14 (−4.04%)
Strain 0.001324 0.001324 0.00 (0.00%)

The calculated envelope and the experimental load-strain curve for specimen #3 are shown in Figure 19. At the yield limit state, the experimental load was measured to be 484.42 kN and the analytical load was calculated as 509.49 kN. At the same time, the strain of the tensile reinforcement was calculated to be 0.004549. When comparing the experimental and analytical values, the load was subject to an error of about −4.92% in the yield limit state. In the elastic region, the calculated envelope and the experimental load-strain curve were very similar. However, in the inelastic region, the strain of the tensile reinforcement of specimen #3 was not recorded because the attached gauge malfunctioned during the transition from the yield limit state to the maximum load limit state. For this reason, an analysis of the measured load-strain curve for specimen #4 (Figure 20), which had the same cross-section as specimen #3, was conducted. From the analyzed envelope, it was found that the experimental values matched the analytical values to strain levels representing the failure limit state. Fig. 19.
Load-strain curve of the tensile reinforcement of specimen #3. Fig. 20.
Load-strain curve of the tensile reinforcement of specimen #4.
The calculated envelope and the experimental load-strain curve for specimen #4 are shown in Figure 20.

sec.title: Analysis of CO2 Emission and Energy Consumption
sec.p:
In this study, energy consumption and CO2 emission were calculated using the Industrial Interdependence Table. The method suggested by Lee et al. (2009) [12] was adopted for the calculation procedure. The energy consumption and CO2 emission per original unit of key material based on the Industrial Interdependence Table are shown in Figures 21 and 22, respectively. Fig. 21.
Energy consumption for major construction materials per original unit. Fig. 22.
CO2 emission of major construction materials per original unit.

To compare the energy consumption and CO2 emission of a steel pre-stressed composite beam with those of RC and SRC beams, these beams were designed as shown in Figures 23 and 24, respectively. The compressive strength of the concrete used in the RC beam was 38.8 MPa, with 548.9 MPa reinforcing steels with diameter of 25mm used for tensile and compressive reinforcement. The maximum load of the RC beam was calculated to be 525.47 kN. The compressive strength of the concrete used in the SRC beam was 38.8 MPa, with a steel frame (H-200 × 200 × 8 × 12), and 548.9 MPa reinforcing steels with diameter of 25 mm used for tensile and compressive reinforcement. The maximum load of the SRC beam was calculated to be 536.79 kN. Fig. 23.
Cross-section of the RC beam. Fig. 24.
Cross-section of the SRC beam.

The energy consumption and CO2 emission of each structural beam are summarized in Figures 25 and 26, respectively. When compared to the RC beam, the pre-stressed composite steel beam reduced the energy consumption and CO2 emission by 2041.21 MJ and 296.87 kg, respectively. In comparison to the SRC beam, the pre-stressed composite steel beam reduced the energy consumption and CO2 emission by 10757.29 MJ and 1437.40 kg, respectively. Fig. 25.
Energy consumption with respect to the structural system. Fig. 26.
CO2 emission with respect to the structural system.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In this work, the flexural moment capacities, energy efficiencies, and CO2 emissions of a steel pre-stressed composite beam, an RC beam, and a steel beam were investigated. The following conclusions were reached:
The strain compatibility method based on the assumption of elastic and inelastic strain distributions leading to the location of the neutral axis was successfully verified upon comparison with the experimental results.
In the experimental testing, specimens #1 and #2 were destroyed when they were subjected to loads of 110∼130 kN. Because the construction load of a pre-cast pre-stressed composite steel beam is 47.44 kN, cracking and destruction of the beam are not expected to occur if specimens #1 and #2 are applied on-site.
The yield load of the pre-stressed composite steel beam in the yield limit state was calculated to be 509.49 kN. In the experiments, the yield loads of specimens #3 and #4 were measured to be 484.42 kN and 503.51 kN, respectively. As a result, the strain compatibility approach is sufficiently reliable.
In the maximum load limit state, the experimental load was measured to be 558.20 kN, while the analytical load was calculated as 524.46 kN. Again, the strain compatibility method is believed to be highly reliable.
Compared to RC and SRC beams, the pre-stressed composite steel beam reduced CO2 emissions by 296.87 kg (17.89%) and 1437.40 kg (51.33%), respectively, and energy consumption by 2041.21 MJ (16.33%) and 10757.29 MJ (50.70%), respectively. Due to its high energy efficiency and lower CO2 emissions, the pre-stressed composite steel beam is expected to support the construction of environmentally friendly and sustainable apartment buildings.
